meta.title: Leadership Frameworks Database
meta.description: Comprehensive collection of leadership frameworks available in Reflacto

sbi.name: SBI Framework
sbi.description: A three-step structure for giving effective feedback by focusing on observable facts rather than personality traits
sbi.purpose: Eliminate defensiveness and provide specific, actionable feedback
sbi.whenToUse: When someone did something specific that had a clear impact - either positive (to reinforce) or problematic (to change)

structure.S: Situation - Describe the specific context when the behavior occurred
structure.B: Behavior - Explain the observable actions or behaviors (facts, not interpretations)
structure.I: Impact - Describe the effect or consequences of the behavior

keyBenefits: Reduces defensiveness by focusing on facts, not personality
Creates clear cause-and-effect understanding
Makes feedback specific and actionable
Works for both positive reinforcement and developmental feedback
sbi.targetAudience: Engineering leaders giving feedback to team members

grow.name: GROW Model
grow.description: A four-step coaching model for structured problem-solving and goal achievement
grow.purpose: Guide systematic thinking from current reality to actionable next steps
grow.whenToUse: When stuck on complex problems, going in circles, or coaching someone who says 'I don't know what to do'

structure.G: Goal - Define what success looks like and desired outcomes
structure.R: Reality - Assess the current situation objectively
structure.O: Options - Generate multiple possible solutions and approaches
structure.W: Will/Way Forward - Commit to specific actions with timelines

keyBenefits: Prevents solving the wrong problem by clarifying goals first
Uncovers options missed due to narrow focus
Transforms vague intentions into specific action steps
Effective for both self-reflection and coaching others
grow.targetAudience: Leaders coaching team members or self-reflecting on complex challenges

mediation.name: Mediation Framework
mediation.description: Structured approach to resolving interpersonal conflicts by focusing on underlying interests rather than positions
mediation.purpose: Transform conflicts from adversarial positions to collaborative problem-solving
mediation.whenToUse: When people are stuck arguing, avoiding each other, or when conflict affects team dynamics

structure.positions: Identify what each party is demanding or insisting upon
structure.interests: Uncover the real needs, concerns, and motivations behind positions
structure.options: Generate solutions that address underlying interests
structure.agreement: Create mutually acceptable resolution both parties help develop

keyBenefits: Gets past surface arguments to real underlying problems
Preserves working relationships instead of creating winners/losers
Both parties own the solution because they helped create it
Addresses root causes to prevent recurring conflicts
mediation.targetAudience: Leaders mediating conflicts between team members or resolving personal conflicts

decision-matrix.name: Decision Matrix
decision-matrix.description: Systematic evaluation of multiple options against weighted criteria to make objective decisions
decision-matrix.purpose: Remove emotional bias and provide clear rationale for complex decisions
decision-matrix.whenToUse: When facing 3+ viable options, need to justify decisions to others, or experiencing decision paralysis

structure.criteria: Define what factors matter most for this decision
structure.weights: Assign importance scores to each criteria
structure.options: List all viable alternatives being considered
structure.scoring: Rate each option against each criteria
structure.calculation: Multiply scores by weights to determine optimal choice

keyBenefits: Breaks decision paralysis with clear winner based on priorities
Shows transparent reasoning process to stakeholders
Forces consideration of all relevant factors
Creates reusable template for similar future decisions
decision-matrix.targetAudience: Leaders making operational team decisions with multiple stakeholders

interest-based-negotiation.name: Interest-Based Negotiation
interest-based-negotiation.description: Harvard-developed approach to resolve conflicts by focusing on mutual interests rather than opposing positions
interest-based-negotiation.purpose: Transform cross-team conflicts from zero-sum competition to collaborative problem-solving
interest-based-negotiation.whenToUse: When teams are blocking each other, have competing priorities, or need solutions both will actually implement

structure.separate: Separate people from the problem - focus on issues not personalities
structure.interests: Focus on underlying interests, not stated positions
structure.options: Generate multiple options for mutual gain
structure.criteria: Use objective criteria to evaluate solutions

keyBenefits: Stops destructive 'us vs them' dynamics
Identifies real constraints each team faces
Creates solutions making both teams more successful
Builds relationships preventing future conflicts
interest-based-negotiation.targetAudience: Leaders resolving conflicts between different teams or departments

pros-cons.name: Pros/Cons Analysis
pros-cons.description: Enhanced pros/cons evaluation considering second-order effects and long-term implications
pros-cons.purpose: Make strategic decisions by analyzing comprehensive advantages and disadvantages
pros-cons.whenToUse: For decisions with significant long-term impact, when justifying choices to leadership, or when obvious choice feels wrong

structure.immediate: List direct pros and cons of each option
structure.secondary: Consider second-order effects and unintended consequences
structure.stakeholders: Identify who is affected and how
structure.alignment: Assess fit with strategic goals and values

keyBenefits: Uncovers hidden costs and unexpected benefits
Forces consideration of long-term strategic alignment
Identifies stakeholder impact and consultation needs
Creates clear record of reasoning for future reference
pros-cons.targetAudience: Senior leaders making strategic organizational decisions

responsibility-mapping.name: RACI Matrix
responsibility-mapping.description: Framework for clarifying roles and responsibilities in complex projects or decisions
responsibility-mapping.purpose: Eliminate confusion about who does what and prevent tasks from falling through cracks
responsibility-mapping.whenToUse: When tasks are dropped, people duplicate work, decisions are slow, or onboarding new team members

structure.R: Responsible - Who does the actual work to complete the task
structure.A: Accountable - Who is ultimately answerable for completion and has decision authority
structure.C: Consulted - Who provides input and expertise before decisions are made
structure.I: Informed - Who needs to know about decisions and progress but doesn't provide input

keyBenefits: Eliminates 'I thought someone else was doing that' problems
Speeds decisions by clarifying who has authority
Prevents work duplication and territorial conflicts
New team members immediately know who to ask about what
responsibility-mapping.targetAudience: Leaders organizing complex projects with multiple stakeholders

bound.name: BOUND Framework
bound.description: Five-step process for resetting unrealistic stakeholder expectations using evidence-based negotiation
bound.purpose: Reset unrealistic expectations while preserving relationships and achieving realistic outcomes
bound.whenToUse: When facing impossible deadlines, unrealistic scope demands, or stakeholders who don't understand technical constraints

structure.B: Baseline - Establish realistic situation based on facts, constraints, and current knowledge
structure.O: Objectivity - Use evidence and reasoning to ground discussions in reality rather than assumptions
structure.U: Understand - Discover underlying needs, concerns, and pressures shaping stakeholder expectations
structure.N: Negotiate - Frame balanced options and trade-offs leading to constructive decisions
structure.D: Document - Capture and share agreements to maintain clarity and alignment over time

keyBenefits: Uses objective evidence instead of opinions for credibility
Uncovers real business drivers behind unrealistic requests
Creates collaborative solutions stakeholders help develop
Documents agreements preventing future scope creep
bound.targetAudience: Technical leaders managing stakeholder expectations and project constraints

alignment-canvas.name: Stakeholder Alignment Framework
alignment-canvas.description: Comprehensive preparation framework for high-stakes leadership conversations requiring buy-in
alignment-canvas.purpose: Organize evidence and anticipate questions for successful leadership engagement
alignment-canvas.whenToUse: Before meetings requiring leadership buy-in, budget approval, or strategic decisions

structure.context: Situational background and why this matters now
structure.evidence: Data, metrics, and proof points supporting the proposal
structure.objections: Anticipated questions and concerns with prepared responses
structure.alternatives: Other options considered and why they were rejected
structure.next-steps: Specific actions and timelines if approved

keyBenefits: Prevents awkward 'I hadn't thought of that' moments
Organizes arguments logically instead of jumping around
Dramatically increases success rate in high-stakes conversations
Demonstrates strategic thinking matching leadership expectations
alignment-canvas.targetAudience: Leaders preparing for executive presentations and strategic decision meetings

delegation-empowerment.name: Delegation/Empowerment Framework
delegation-empowerment.description: Framework for effective delegation that develops people's judgment while maintaining appropriate oversight
delegation-empowerment.purpose: Empower team members with context and authority to make decisions within clear boundaries
delegation-empowerment.whenToUse: When you're the bottleneck for decisions, want to develop someone's judgment, or need things to happen without constant involvement

structure.context: Provide background on why this matters and how it fits bigger picture
structure.authority: Define decision-making authority and boundaries clearly
structure.resources: Ensure access to necessary information, tools, and support
structure.checkpoints: Establish regular touchpoints for guidance and course correction
structure.outcomes: Define success criteria and how results will be measured

keyBenefits: Develops people's judgment for better long-term decision making
Frees leaders from daily operational bottlenecks
Creates teams that function independently
Increases ownership and engagement through meaningful authority
delegation-empowerment.targetAudience: Leaders developing team members and scaling organizational capacity

five-dysfunctions.name: Five Dysfunctions of a Team
five-dysfunctions.description: Hierarchical model identifying root causes of team dysfunction starting with trust as the foundation
five-dysfunctions.purpose: Diagnose team health issues and identify which dysfunction to address first for maximum impact
five-dysfunctions.whenToUse: When teams feel 'off' but you can't pinpoint why, meetings are polite but unproductive, or people seem disengaged

structure.trust: Absence of trust - team members don't feel safe being vulnerable with each other
structure.conflict: Fear of conflict - artificial harmony prevents productive disagreement
structure.commitment: Lack of commitment - without healthy conflict, there's no real buy-in to decisions
structure.accountability: Avoidance of accountability - team members don't hold each other accountable
structure.results: Inattention to results - focus on individual goals over collective team success

keyBenefits: Identifies root problems instead of treating symptoms
Shows which dysfunction to fix first since they build hierarchically
Based on research with thousands of teams across industries
Provides specific interventions for each level of team development
five-dysfunctions.targetAudience: Team leaders diagnosing and improving team dynamics and performance

feedforward-coaching.name: Feedforward Coaching
feedforward-coaching.description: Coaching approach focused on future improvement rather than past mistakes to eliminate defensiveness
feedforward-coaching.purpose: Facilitate productive peer feedback conversations that build relationships rather than create resentment
feedforward-coaching.whenToUse: When facilitating feedback between team members, especially with existing tension or past feedback failures

structure.future-focus: Focus conversation on 'what would work better next time' instead of 'what went wrong'
structure.specific-actions: Generate concrete, actionable suggestions people can implement
structure.strengths-based: Build on existing strengths rather than just fixing weaknesses
structure.ownership: Let people choose which suggestions resonate and commit to trying
structure.follow-up: Establish check-ins to support implementation and recognize progress

keyBenefits: Eliminates defensiveness by avoiding re-litigation of past mistakes
Creates specific actionable improvements instead of vague advice
Actually strengthens relationships through collaborative problem-solving
People get excited about growth instead of defensive about criticism
feedforward-coaching.targetAudience: Leaders facilitating peer feedback and team member development conversations
